content:
ry 29, 2016
												This was certainly better and longer than expected.In its core it is mostly Zelda and final fantasy gameplaywise, with short references into other games, thus this being part of what (admittedly small) length it has.  It uses those 2 rather well though, allthough the random encounters felt far too frequent. You unlock new graphics etc. by opening chests zeldastyle.To get 100% you will probably need a couple more hours without google, since the game is pretty good at hiding goodies or even entire areas and at locking them behind puzzles. Without any sidedestractions id say you will beat this in 3 hours at most though.There isnt a reason to go 100% other than the sense of achievement either, since the game isnt exactly keen on giving away cool stuff, which is also part of what bothered me: I beat your little mini cardgame with 10 cards, in every difficulty I dont WANT the other 13, I dont WANT another hidden star, i want some cool kind of equipment. The music is pretty decent sometimes but mostly just gets the job done. Perhaps I entirely missed so many hidden audial messages in the music, aside from the expected 8-bit to 16-bit etc switch, but in case I didnt I think it would have been decent to think of something there, since this tries to represent the evolution of games and boy did music evolve with it.Graphicwise it is pretty cool that they added quite a few layers between first and final graphics (with jabs at "HD" versions of stuff from the past that still looked like crap), but I still feel like they could have done more steps in between, and the final graphics look kind of ugly in my opinion as well. Going fruther than that would have also enabled more steps in between.The story is absolutely not worth mentioning, it wont be why you played this, same goes for character development etc.All together I love it though, it is full of hidden references, it copy pastes gameplay from the other games in ways that work well and I love the idea in general, very decent for a part 1 gonna play part 2 now and hope a lot of things improved. Is it worth 10 dollars though? Hmmm that depends on if "well that was kinda fun" as a result after 3 hours is worth 10 dollars to you. I guess most would say no and should wait on a sale

y 2, 2014
												   An enjoyable gaming experience for anyone who grew with the early rpgs. This game is a great game for Redditors and fans of Family Guy as much like those things, this game brings almost nothing new and interesting to its format, and steals (relativiely poorly at that) all it's aspects from other games. Even a majority of the enemies are simply references to other games.    There are 3 games this game takes most of its gameplay mechanics directly from; Legend of Zelda, Final Fantasy, and Diablo. This would be ok if this game blended these playstyles together well, unfortunateley this is not the case. Instead you really just find yourself playing 3 different games that are really not connected to one another. leveling up in the final fantasy gameplay has no bearing on how play in the other games. The same can be said about the loot you get from the Diablo scenario.  Overall if you like those games this game will be an enjoyable playthrough (especially since it's incredibly short), but the originality leaves something to be desired, and the flow of the game is entirely too chopped up. Well worth the sale price of 2$ but hardly worth a penny more.   A solid 6/10

content:
, 2014
												The game was developed during the 24th LUDUM DARE competition, and that's the problem: 48 hours to create a game concept, and anyone can see its limits. Kudos to Nicolas Cannasse for sure, but Evoland is still a really boring game with childish structure, that mocks 3 big series (Final Fantasy, Zelda and Diablo), without even scratch the surface of one of them."What did you expect from a 48hrs game?". Nothing good, if not a glimpse of something that could have been good, if they had more time.The idea of a treasure trove that Evolves an old GBA game to a nowadays game (sort of) is good. The rest... ALL the rest (game mechanics, levels, interface and interaction) is not. They're just ideas joined together with tape and glue. I understand is not easy putting together something fast and with so many layers of famous mechanics, but I'm not for half-done games and boring wannabes.My compliments for the winning, but as a whole, this game is to avoid. Sorry.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
4, 2014
												Cannot recommend this game. Sadly. It definitely took some work and have some nice aestethics at times. Yet, what a complete blunder both as a game and as a tribute to games. Can't say it any more nicely.Now, let's start picking this game apart. It becomes obvious from the first minutes, that this game was made with sole purpose of referencing and tributing old Action-RPG games (from 8 bit up to Diablo 1, as far as I gathered). Now, that in itself isn't a bad idea and leaves some room for leniancy when judging it as a game. Still, you cannot do sloppy job here.1) First and foremost, I personally found references to be... dull? I get what they mean, I get what they are referencing, but realization is simply uninspired. Like "hey, remember how good it was to actually have a heart healthbar in Zelda?". Well... yeah, I guess. So what? And this "so what?" remains unanswered till the very end. This is not some complete and independent game, where "tribute" serves sole purpose of Easter Egg. You built this game around the very notion of tributes. You can't simply reference the games and leave it at that. Simple reference can't replace gameplay, it can't be entertaining on its own without YOU, as a developer, MAKING it entertaining. Make witty remarks, push old mechanic to absurdity, demonstrating how flawed it was (or maybe better than modern?). Take your cues from "Bard's Tale" made in 2005. It seriously lacked in gameplay, but still kept player invested, because it provided witty remarks non-stop. It didn't simply reference "oh, in Diablo stuff drop from mobs". It referenced "hey, remember when you got your rare armor from wolf? Isn't it kinda funny how wolf actually carries something worthless to itself?". It didn't simply reference, it scrutinized, studied, demonstrated how silly and funny those things that we accepted before were (and many still are!) about Action-RPG games. Not simple notebook containing notes about old, but a full fledged monologue from developers to player, through their game. Monologue which more often than not felt like dialogue.2) Very bland and primitive gameplay. Yes, I know, I stated above that in this case some leniency may be given. But not THAT much, as per my opinion. You reference random encounters from Final Fantasy and what not? Well, okay. But why, for the love of all that is living, are you making them so boring, so dumb, so mind numbingly NOT FUN. It is one of the most controversial points of jRPGs in itself, the boring grinding, 99% fights which don't require ANY input other than mashing single button. You didn't simply reference old games. You presented some elements in the abhorent and repulsive way. And then FORCED player to play in this framework. What the hell? You can't claim you're demonstrating how boring random encounters are when you force player through them for 1/2-3/4 of the game. It completely misses the point. Either do those mechanics in an entertaining manner or refrain from pushing them onto player for the majority of the game. Take your cues from "Cthulhu saves the world", made not too long ago by indie developer. Yes, they to reference a lot of jRPGs, mostly jRPGs. But they also bring to the table a very solid and intresting mechanic into random encounters. Moreover, they introduce "random encounter limit" for each location, when after certain number of battles you are no longer forced through those fights with those enemies. You still can farm using specific option in character menu and people don't feel punished for retracing their steps and checking every corner for secrets. This is what this game should've been about. You reference old games and present solid entertaining mechanics from them while you're at it. You cannot force down the throat mechanics, that are much worse than even those you reference in the first place. And we're talking about Final Fantasy, the mother of all "boring and uninspiring" random encounters, the epithomy of the problem both in days of old and modern age. Yet even in those games certain steps were taken to ensure at least some interest and diversity. When you introduced Babamut in your game, it was a point where you should've made him a "one-button-win-them-all" ability, which would allow to travel the world and wrap up the remaining secrets. Yet even there you introduced ~5 real minute timer. Real minute. For crying out loud... why this? What purpose does it serve? You consider that at that point ANYTHING from random encounters can actually pose a threat to player big enough that it will make fight not trivial? You're wrong, your random encounter mechanic is too flawed and too primitive from the beginning. You can't exactly make a challenging fight when your character can do only two things - hit or heal. Literally.3) While the rest of the references and mechanics aren't AS bad as those described in second point, they are too bland and uninspired most of the time. This game, while trying to reference many others, falls flat at each and every one of the attempts. It never begins to come close to NES Zelda in terms of combat, it never begins to come close to Diablo. Puzzles and trap sections are way too primitive and boring, so much that I actually couldn't remember any of the location and basic order of rooms right after leaving it. It was THAT boring. Yet there was intresting mechanic, with time changing. If only developers focused on this mechanic, made it more pronounced and built game around it. But no, it mostly serves secondary purpose in some of the puzzles. The rest is a mesh of "hey, we tried to make X reference, but kinda stopped at the very beginning". I understand, that it would be way too hard to make many good games inside one game. Don't. Make ONE good game and shift its mechanics slightly to represent your references. You'll be surprised how much being subtle and precise will enhance your points. Consider it an uncanny valley of sort, sometimes small changes are much more pronounced because you can compare it to almost same thing.In the end, I cannot recommend this to anyone. Two games I mentioned above, "Bard's Tale" and "Cthulhu saves the world" provide much bigger impact. And even without them this game is too bland to be both the reference book and an enjoyable game. I sincerely hope that developers will try their hand once again, but this time put much more effort in concept and basic mechanics.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
er 28, 2013
												Evoland is a game with a good concept but terrible execution. In Evoland you go through the different ages of video games; from 2D to 3D, and even through different styles of games like Diablo, Zelda and Final Fantasy. It sounds pretty cool right? However I was very disappointed with the game. My biggest problem with Evoland is that everything is so simple. The games Evoland are referencing are fairly complex (like Zelda and Diablo) but since Evoland lacks depth these sections quickly lost their charm and became a massive grind. Relying on the occasional funny reference to keep you playing. The worst offender was the Final Fantasy section. This area has timed battles, but the the main character can only attack and heal which made these sections so frustrating to play. There's no summons, leveling up or any of the depth that FF has (you can't even heal OUTSIDE of battle). Depth is what makes Final Fantasy fun. Like think of the difference between a level 1 and level 50 character, now you're forced to play as the level 1 character for the entire game... yay?Next the story... it sucks. Early on it's fine since stories weren't a big focus back then... but it never improves. You only ever get 2 party members and by the FF section the story is still "the bad guy is doing bad things, kill him". I wish the story went completely wacky and over the top (as FF's are known to do) but it never puts in the effort to improve it. The game is also filled with unmemorable and bland characters which doesn't help.The rest of the game handles fine. The music's nice with some good tunes, the controls are smooth and the artstyle changes with the different eras of gaming (from 2D to full 3D models). For anyone wondering these changes happen after you find them in a chest.Evoland relies on nostalgia and witty remarks over good gameplay and story. You might find a funny reference, but at the end of the day the game is so shallow that it just feels like a waste of money. I finished it in two and a half hours and I would not recommened Evoland.

content:
2, 2014
												I don't know how a game that is only 2 hours long can manage to so thoroughly overstay its welcome, but Evoland achieves it with such ease that even half way through I could barely stand it anymore. The game jumps often from mechanic to mechanic, each time executing its new mechanics even worse than it did the previous ones. Starting as a clunky, imprecise Zelda clone it swiftly shifts gears into a dull and grindy Final Fantasy Clone, switching back and fourth between the two for a couple dungeons before introducing the worst possible Diablo clone ever conceived. Finishing off, it moves to a side scrolling action sequence for the last boss. The boss itself is dull and predictable, but due to unresponsive controls, tiny hitboxes, and him having more health than god, the fight with only two phases, each only having a single attack pattern can draw out for 20 minutes.The game wouldn't even be so bad if it were at least moderately consistant between mechanics, but it basically throws everything away when you move to a new section. The bombs and arrows you get in the zelda sequence can't be used in the Final Fantasy section, so you end up just mashing attack and waiting for everything to die. The potions, healing spells and phoenix downs you get in the Final Fantasy section can't be used in the Zelda, Diablo or Final boss sections, something that even contradicts the "plot" of the game. All the "power" you obtain before the final boss, a power which is supposed to help you defeat him, goes completely unused because none of those abilities are available outside of the Final Fantasy sections.Evoland is a novel idea executed in the worst possible way.

The idea of slowly expanding and evolving the world around you is really cool, but the world itself ends up being very bland.The combat is typical, boring, and repetitive. And jeez is the end anti-climactic and boring.Evoland is a game that was probably way more interesting when it first came out, but at this point you are probably way better off passing this by and looking at its sequel instead.

												I'm really on the fence about Evoland. This is a really awesome homage of console RPG video game history. It got alot of smiles from me. There is alot of Final Fantasy and Zelda, and little hints of Super Mario Bros., among others. You start in black-and-white with no sound or frills, and gradually earn more modern luxuries in video games. We are talking everything up to 3D and high res textures!Even though I am 'not recommending', please don't get it twisted - this game is a success. It certainly does what it set out to do. I am in love with the idea and follow-through, I am just not so happy with some of the actual gaming elements.Pros:+Super cool idea+Awesome throw-back to gaming of old that gets great smilesCons:-Fighting, which is something you obviously do alot of, is awkward and not fun-While the actual gameplay is a throw-back, gaming has evolved in many ways from 'get the key, find the door' which turns me off (it still exists but is certainly more masked)-Listen up, this is a huge complaint: the store front claims full controller support, which it has, but is very very poor. You have to muck with files to get it to work each and every single time you play. No thanks.-Storyline is super genericI got it on sale over at HumbleBundle. I don't regret it, but it is what it is.

content:
ber 12, 2015
 Evoland Evoland is a cute little game that takes you through the history of J-RPG games. Visual: 8/10 It is very difficult to review evolands graphics and art-style, as it changes multiple times...The game starts off with a simple colourless 8bit style, similar to the first pokémon games, but it quickly evolves and gains colour. Eventually the game turns 3d, and that's the end of it.The art style nails what it tries to do, which is replicating RPG games throughout the ages. I do think that it's good for what it is, but the need to replicate it makes the art-style boring. Sound 6/10 The music in Evoland is mediocre through the entire game. There aren't any memorable chiptune tracks in the earlier part of the game, or any epic battle songs in the later part of the game. Honestly I had to google the soundtrack and listen again while writing this to make sure that I wasn't talking out of my ♥♥♥♥. Gameplay: 7/10 The gameplay is slightly above average. There was hardly any depth to the gameplay since they had to shove so many different combat types in the game. They started off with a style similar to The Legend of Zelda (Yes, the first one!), then they moved over to a typical turn-based J-RPG style, similar to the older final fantasy games or the pokémon games. The second reason as to why there is no depth is that the game is so shockingly short. I beat the game over the course of approximately 3 hours and I played quite slowly and looked for secrets. Time/Money: 4/10 I beat the game over the course of 3 hours (as mentioned above.) and bought it for the full 9,99€. By using the witchcraft that is commonly known as simple division, I figured out that I spent approximately 3,33€. Keep in mind that I played the game slowly, so if you enjoy speeding through games, then your cash per hour will increase. If your not comfortable to pay 10€ for 2-4 hours of gameplay that is mediocre at best, then you probably shouldn't get this game.

content:
r 18, 2014
												Evoland is a trip through some of the worst features of games past, and reminds you why developers have since moved on to better mechanics.  Here are a few of them that the game indulges:1. One-hit game overs - You're in this mode at the beginning of the game.  Add to it that you're on a grid and so are the randomly-moving enemies, and it's a recipe for disaster.  I died at least 3 or 4 times, starting the whole game over every time, before I could reach the first save point.2. Really annoying low-health sounds - I get it that we're supposed to be careful, but come on.  It sounds like the alarm clock from hell, and I had to actually shut off the sound when it came on.  Don't believe me?  Search for it on YouTube and listen for yourself.3. Backtracking - Notice that chest that seems impossible to get to?  That's right, if you want to get 100% completion, you're going to have to backtrack a LOT.  You only get certain skills later in the game, and will have to head back to earlier areas to use them to get all the collectables.  The game world isn't massive, but the random encounters will be fighting you every step of the way.4. Loading screens - Yeah, yeah, reading data from disks on the PS1 was a tad slow, I get it.  But don't give us artificial loading screens at every one of the four area transitions in a town, and especially not in a town with...5. Multi-layered fetch quests - We need bombs!  That guy probably has some! "Well I used to, but not anymore.  Go talk to that gal."  ...and you finally get the bombs FIVE PEOPLE (and even more loading screens) later.6. A lack of mid-boss checkpoints - Figure out the boss's first stage, only to get stomped flat on the second?  Too bad!  You get to fight the entire thing all over again.  (I normally wouldn't complain, but the second stage is essentially random and requires a lot more luck than skill.)While interesting at least in concept, it doesn't stand up in practice.  Aside from the interesting time travel puzzle and the surprisingly functional Diablo section, it's all incredibly boring and tedious.  You're much better off playing the games it borrows from (2D Zeldas, Final Fantasy VII, Diablo), than this mess.

												This charming game grabs a fistful of nostalgia and hits any gamer around during the early years straight in the face. At it's core it's a fairly simple game made up of popular mechanics that tells a tale we've already heard... but considering it's made of games we've already played, that makes sense, right? The Zelda-like dungeons were clever, although I'm a little annoyed by walk-through walls to hide collectibles.I thoroughly enjoyed the game, although I'm sad it was so short. My game time is only so high because I grabbed all the achievements; the story itself could be done in probably a 2 or 3 hour session the first time. I value games on average (more or less depending on reviews/hype) at $1 per hour of gameplay, and since I got this game on the summer sale it was very much worth it. I'd probably still recommend it at the full $10 price, but it doesn't hurt to slap it on a wishlist and wait for some sort of sale or discount. Much like a Zelda game, I'll probably not touch the game again for a few years and then randomly pick it back up to play through in an afternoon or two.I'd give this game a 7.5/10.

I thoroughly enjoyed this game and do recommend it. The game is very unique and makes many smart and funny references to gaming history and other games. The entire game is essentially an easter egg. It's a very fun game with great music, and I enjoyed it from start to finish. It's a brilliant idea, but unfortunately has a fairly average execution, and those looking for an amazing high quality RPG experience won't find it here.The thing is, the game could have been so much more, it had great potential that it unfortunately didn't reach. I would have liked to see more ideas and mechanics implemented, with a better than average execution. That being said, I still found myself enjoying it from start to finish. It was fun, and although I would have liked more from the combat system, I did enjoy the battles. Not to mention, the music is great and really adds to the experience. By the end, I found myself pleasantly surprised.So all in all, I did have a blast playing this game and do recommend it, however, those looking for a great RPG won't find it here, and may want to wait for a price drop before picking it up. It is a fun game that is worth picking up in my opinion, but maybe not for the full price.

												This is a gem you wouldn't wanna miss. While others think that the concepts became switched up mid-game and misapplied, I feel as if it has a linear progression to it. The game starts off, with the very humble begginings of how video games started. Then, you must collect upgrades which takes you on a trip through video game history, showing milestones we have achieved through time with things such as; better graphics, different point-of-views, and combat systems. It heavily references to Zelda and Final Fantasy, calling for some fine nestalgia. For the price The game is more than worth it, especially if you like upgrade games with adventuring mechanics. It's just whatd you expect out of a $10 game, but with a tad more captivity. Sure, they could have implemented more to the rather short game, but I feel to them it was more than just a game, it also traversed you through the history of video games itself and to me, was a very fun experience.

												I don't recommend Evoland.I beat the game in 2-3 hours using an x360 controller. It is neat to start out with b&w 2d graphics and slowly watch them become better, but the feeling runs dry in the first hour. The game is completely linear and serves mostly as a tech demo for all the different puzzles, playstyles, and visuals that the many adventure games of the past have already done.Any type of major puzzle used to block progress that you can think of has probably been used. Burn down saplings so that they don't block your path when you teleport to the future (Oracle of Ages/Seasons.) Find the right path to walk across a room or you will fall through the floor (Link to the Past.) Bomb through cracked walls. Find all switches. Push blocks to make a path. And so on.Most combat is in 2d Zelda format, followed by turn-based, FF style battles, and some light ARPG style combat. Evoland is not unpleasant, but with no real story, it's not exactly memorable either.

												Evoland has really clunky controls and a poorly written story that feels hastily put together.  I beat this game and 100%'d the achievements in just over ten hours, then I uninstalled it, and I don't know if I'll ever play it again. But don't let that discourage you from making this purchase.Evoland is a wonderful trip through the history of video games.  Its a homage to the entire genre of Action/Adventure games.  Its full of quips and references to so many of the classic games centering around Zelda and Final Fantasy.  Two games I've never played, in fact I only caught a couple nods towards other games but have had friends point out many more to me.  I bought this game to enjoy a little trip down memory lane and experience what I thought was a fun way to appreciate the evolution of games.And that's exactly what this is.If you weren't around for the early days of gaming, then this game will give you that glimpse of a part of video games you've missed.  I thoroughly enjoyed every minute I spent in this game and will think fondly of it.  But it has little replay value, so I probably wont play it again.

												I really wanted to like this game, but I just can't. To best describe it, it basically tries to pay homage to The Legend of Zelda, Final Fantasy, and Diablo for the most part. The only sections I found fun in the slightest were the boss of the sole Diablo section, and very small parts of the Zelda pieces. The Final Fantasy mechanics were not enjoyable at all. It has you spamming the Action button to select your main attack, and then repeat until all the enemies die. The random encounters are especially annoying because of this. There's also a lot of questionable design choices. For instance, when you die, you go to the main menu. Rather than just get a normal game over screen. The saving is left to odd save points that end up just costing you unnecessary time. There's a lot more that I don't want to type out, though.In addition, past the first few areas, the writing is god awful. It doesn't seem to follow proper grammar, and if it does, then it's doing an extremely poor job of writing in general. First few areas had funny text, but none past that.All in all a poor game. I wouldn't reccomend spending your time or money on it.To the dev: I hope your next game is a hell of a lot better than this.

content:
0, 2015
												1.2 hours in: Enjoyed the quickly evolving graphics/playstyle as you run around. Hack and slash mechanics are fun, as are the turn based battles (makes me want to play some Final Fantasy games). I've gone through one dungeon and fought a boss. Wasn't difficult, more just figuring out the mechanics of the fight and doing the right thing at the right time. So far, enjoying the game and want to play more!2 hours in: I've finished the story up to the last boss. Let's be honest here, not an amazing story. The time travelling section was more tedious than creative or tricky. I plan to collect all of the hidden items in the game, but I think that may wait as I just don't really feel like playing more at the moment. But I do want to 100% the game. 6 hours in (I admit some of that time was spent afk with the game open): Just got 100% completion on the game. Was definitely tricky to find some of the hidden stars/cards, but once you figure out where you need to go, you can usually find the ones you missed the first time around (hint: wall hugging is a good idea). Some of the end game areas were rather tricky with the time travelling mechanic, so that was nice. The final boss was actually quite perfect. Took me a few tries to understand how it worked, but once I did, I was able to down him quite easily. Overall, I would say it's an enjoyable game. After the first hour, you've pretty much unlocked all of the visual and/or mechanic upgrades that you are going to get. That being said, I did enjoy playing through different game styles; it was definitely fun and brought back some great memories of other games. I don't think there is much replay-ability with this one. I would say the game is worth at least half price. Definitely enjoyable, but gets a bit repetitive after the first hour when you are going back and hunting treasures. I think I physically played the game maybe four hours, so I would recommend, but only if it's on a sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
y 10, 2014
												Evoland is a hilarious title brimming with nostalgia. The number of times it cracked a grin on my face or made me laugh was more than the number of dollars it cost... until it stopped evolving (which was maybe 90 minutes in). Then it was just "crappy FF / Diablo / Zelda land" with a hard emphasis on the crappy.The best hours of gameplay are the first 2, the game is pretty short (I did literally everything in 10.3 hours), and the fact that it took no effort to make its Final Fantasy random encounter battles at all interesting (which end up being a good chunk of the middle of the game) are some pretty big downsides.There are definitely some funny parts and some nostalgia pangs to be had. If you absolutely loved Final Fantasy 7 and old school Zeldas, and you find this on sale, you can probably expect to get your money's worth.You'll likely get 6-10 hours of gameplay, with no replayability except possibly to show a friend the first hour of it which is a very interesting look back into the history of game development.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
y 11, 2014
												I would almost consider this game a tragedy if it were longer or had more effort put into it, because perhaps then it would inadvertantly be a failure instead of just a lazy piece of garbage. Its sole selling point is of course the gradual unlocking of basic game features meant to mimic the growth of genres over the decades. Unfortunately it gives up on this gimmick after surprisingly little gameplay, gameplay elements come up once or twice at best, only the Zelda-esque segments are at all fleshed out (and even then, you only get a grand total of 2 items and 4 significant mechanics... including those items), the writing is barely even worth calling a parody with so little effort put into it, and the game comes to a screeching halt after the second town. The jRPG side of things only ever features 3 spells/skills, no MP, and no strategy whatsoever. How this can be called an "homage" or an "affectionate parody" when the creators can't be bothered to achieve a tenth of the gameplay complexity of even the original Final Fantasy is beyond me.Oh, and when the selling points say "Revisit the starting area rendered in full 3D or explore the overworld with your own airship!" they only mean the very first dungeon-y area you start out in, not the first officially recognized dungeon, and not the first town. The game makers couldn't be bothered to render those in 3D. (And the world you get to "explore" on the airship is TINY.)With such a lack of content, coherency, consistency, features, affection, or even effort, the only favorable way I could describe this is "a tech demo," and it is certainly not worth its full price of $9.99.

content:
y 8, 2014
												Neat concept, but lacking in implimentation. Gameplay is pretty shallow, and while the references to game culture and RPGs of old is fun at first, it starts to wear thin really quick.A simple example is this. You open chests to unlock "features", for example, moving left or right, or up and down, to music, experience points and every other improvement, gameplay or graphical throughout the game. However, you eventually gain 3D graphics and a camera zoom in for when you open chests. When you reach this point you can only open chests from a specific side, and have to wait for both the player's animation and camera animation to stop to continue the game. This is after having chests that opened instantaniously and didn't pause player progression. This is just one example of how something wasn't throught out past the initial concept, and the game seems to be full of these. after about 45 minutes of play and two dungeons I was incredibly bored and felt like I had seen everything the game had to offer. Spending 6 hours to complete the game just didn't feel worth it at that point.Again, the concept is great, but it's all fluff with no substance it feels like.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2015
I thoroughly enjoyed this game and do recommend it. The game is very unique and makes many smart and funny references to gaming history and other games. The entire game is essentially an easter egg. It's a very fun game with great music, and I enjoyed it from start to finish. It's a brilliant idea, but unfortunately has a fairly average execution, and those looking for an amazing high quality RPG experience won't find it here.The thing is, the game could have been so much more, it had great potential that it unfortunately didn't reach. I would have liked to see more ideas and mechanics implemented, with a better than average execution. That being said, I still found myself enjoying it from start to finish. It was fun, and although I would have liked more from the combat system, I did enjoy the battles. Not to mention, the music is great and really adds to the experience. By the end, I found myself pleasantly surprised.So all in all, I did have a blast playing this game and do recommend it, however, those looking for a great RPG won't find it here, and may want to wait for a price drop before picking it up. It is a fun game that is worth picking up in my opinion, but maybe not for the full price.

content:
2, 2015
												This charming game grabs a fistful of nostalgia and hits any gamer around during the early years straight in the face. At it's core it's a fairly simple game made up of popular mechanics that tells a tale we've already heard... but considering it's made of games we've already played, that makes sense, right? The Zelda-like dungeons were clever, although I'm a little annoyed by walk-through walls to hide collectibles.I thoroughly enjoyed the game, although I'm sad it was so short. My game time is only so high because I grabbed all the achievements; the story itself could be done in probably a 2 or 3 hour session the first time. I value games on average (more or less depending on reviews/hype) at $1 per hour of gameplay, and since I got this game on the summer sale it was very much worth it. I'd probably still recommend it at the full $10 price, but it doesn't hurt to slap it on a wishlist and wait for some sort of sale or discount. Much like a Zelda game, I'll probably not touch the game again for a few years and then randomly pick it back up to play through in an afternoon or two.I'd give this game a 7.5/10.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
7, 2013
												As it turns out, the entire history of [action/adventure] video games can be summarised by mashing together Zelda and FF7. Literally that is all this game is. It starts out all interesting by going through the motions of evolving controls, graphics, sound and all that before just completely ripping off the two aforementioned with a very minor Torchlight-esque sectionette and Triple Triad card game (without even a catchy BGM to go with it). Also a nod to UT's announcer with text kill streaks popping up and a Minecraft item. Still, thats barely a handful of games.Granted, its quite impressive for a small indie team to pump out but it was perhaps too big an undertaking for them to utilise to its full potential. Its too quick to climax, forgets what it was doing and then just proceeds to end on a low. Much could have been done if it continued its tongue-in-cheek parodies while exploring other genres, even if it kept its Zelda/FF overworld, there could have been multiple dungeons covering them like it did with what it claimed to be Diablo but felt more like Torchlight.Like a firework; this game provides wonderful anticipation when lit and a grand display upon exploding but the only way to know its all over is when you hear the distant "thunk" of it hitting the ground in the distance. And even thats only two and a half hours worth of time. Bloody long-♥♥♥♥ firework, that.

content:
er 28, 2013
												If you're picking up this game for the nostalgia factor, I'll give you a word of advice: Don't.I don't care if it looks cool or something that may interest you, this is just a bad game.I will admit, the graphics are pretty good and the concept's enjoyable, it's just heavily flawed and priced at $10 which feels like $5 more than I would care to give it.You see, Evoland is a game ABOUT the nostalgia factor, it embraces the tropes of its forefathers and parodies it in a delightful (if not openly obvious) manner, the gameplay takes time to be varied to show the evolution of the Adventure RPG, and it even comes with a cute little card game which is genuinely interesting. But it's ABOUT the nostalgia factor, so rather than be a game that can stand on its own, it makes itself feel like every game it "showcases," just not as fun. Its most unique feature is a point in the game where you can shift between the "past" and the "future" to make it through an area, which was enjoyable! But that's literally the only unique feature it has. The rest is a lackluster adventure that is blatantly inferior to every game it pays homage to.If there's one good thing Evoland does, it serves as an example when games choose to be retro, thinking that it would be simple, and put no thought into just what made it simple and fun. While it may be funny, that isn't enough to justify a four hour slog.

content:
er 28, 2013
												Evoland is, definitively, the worst game I have ever played. It feels a rushed, half-♥♥♥♥♥ attempt to make use of a cool concept.A major fault of the game is simply in the amount of content; it says that it will take you through history of gaming. Yet the only thing it delivers on is having a couple of sections kinda like Zelda, Final Fantasy, and Diablo.Is that all the gaming history there is? What about some point and click? what about real time strategy? The other problem is the quality of the limited amount of content. Throughout the 2-4 hours of the FF section of the game, you have literally 0-1 spells. And the amount of times you will randomly encounter enemies is absurd. You will sit there spamming left click as the repetitive battle animations play for the same 2-3 enemies in the game. The difficulty in this section is either stupid-hard because your survival is based on your luck not encountering a random enemy. OR stupid-easy because you have a spell that will heal you more then enemies can damage you, so you can just spam it and live through anything.The Diablo section has only 1 button. You spam it three times to do a slightly more powerful move. You do this for about an hour after which you leave this section. ...Yup that's it.The Zelda Section is probably the best it offers so alright puzzles and some actual non-receptive crap content. However this section is less then 1/3 of the game. Not to say this section is "good" just not as horrendous as the others.All in all, worst game I ever played. Literally painful to play. Buy yourself some ice-cream instead it offers more enjoyment.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
er 2, 2013
												A loving parody. Evoland is unquestionably that. It conjures memories of the all-time greatest RPGs, like Legend of Zelda, Final Fantasy, Diablo, and Dragonball Z.Yes, that is definitely all of them. No other RPGs have ever been significant.I can't help but gawk at the lack of content. This is supposed to be an homage to the history of RPGs? This feels like I paid for a tour of an art museum, and was shown three rooms before being thrown out onto the street. The laziness shows through at the seams. They didn't even bother arranging the small amount of content they had into a full map, instead clustering every location together and then filling three-quarters of the world with impassable mountains.The length of the story is also a disappointment. Part of the problem might be that it does the job of reminding you of other games too well, or at the least, too bluntly. Despite the fact that many great RPGs can be completed in a single sitting, this game fails to acknowledge those games at all, choosing instead to constantly reference series that create the expectation that both the storyline and the difficulty curve will be slowly, patiently built up. However, since this game is so short, that doesn't happen. The endgame remains pitifully easy, and the "expected" RPG scenes play out in quick succession without bothering to give you enough context to make anything matter.It doesn't even work as a parody. It's about on par with the "Movie" movies. References are not the same as jokes. The few actual jokes that could have been funny are skimmed over in favor of getting on to the next thing as quickly as possible. Don't buy this game as a gift for a friend. Buy it as a gift for an enemy. Then apologize.

"Remember when games like this were challenging?" Evoland reminisces.  Again, yes.  But your game is not hard and it's not very fun.  It's a simple tour of the past.Players should keep their nostalgia glasses to remember great, old games.  You will not remember Evoland.

content:
, 2015
												Great, great, GREAT concept. Fantastic art, decent music, decent gameplay. This game does not do anything that you haven't seen before... and still manages to be original.However, the game is a bit short (4 hours, 6 if you want full completion). It also suffers from a sometimes questionable level design, and a repetitive soundtrack. Finally, Evoland suffers from a pretty major pacing problem. Early on, you will keep on noting how clever the mechanics are, how cool the nods and references to videogames tropes feel, and how the world is evolving with you. However by mid-game, this sensation will be gone - not because you get used to it, but simply because the game stops throwing anything your way. It just becomes a barebone version of existing games, and by the end you may find yourself thinking you'd rather play the masterpieces Evoland references rather than Evoland itself.Evoland is a brilliant idea, and an absolutely cute game which loves to take advantage of your gamer instincts and reflexes. Sadly besides its concept, the game itself is a bit stale, if not repetitive. I didn't think I'd say this one day, but I wish the game held your hand more, because this is where the game shines. Evoland starts off strong, and ends rather weakly. The games has tones of potential, and for the prices, it is definitely worth getting a look at, but don't expect too much out of it.With all that said, I am extremely excited for the upcoming sequel. Evoland is a rough diamond and with enough polish, could be a BRILLIANT game. Wait and see...

By the time I finished the game, and I realized it was only 3 hours, I was surprised (in a bad way).I do not recommend this game at the price it is being sold at.  There is no replayablility, and what is there isn't that interesting.  I'm disappointed that this great idea was not executed in a professional manner.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
7, 2013
												As it turns out, the entire history of [action/adventure] video games can be summarised by mashing together Zelda and FF7. Literally that is all this game is. It starts out all interesting by going through the motions of evolving controls, graphics, sound and all that before just completely ripping off the two aforementioned with a very minor Torchlight-esque sectionette and Triple Triad card game (without even a catchy BGM to go with it). Also a nod to UT's announcer with text kill streaks popping up and a Minecraft item. Still, thats barely a handful of games.Granted, its quite impressive for a small indie team to pump out but it was perhaps too big an undertaking for them to utilise to its full potential. Its too quick to climax, forgets what it was doing and then just proceeds to end on a low. Much could have been done if it continued its tongue-in-cheek parodies while exploring other genres, even if it kept its Zelda/FF overworld, there could have been multiple dungeons covering them like it did with what it claimed to be Diablo but felt more like Torchlight.Like a firework; this game provides wonderful anticipation when lit and a grand display upon exploding but the only way to know its all over is when you hear the distant "thunk" of it hitting the ground in the distance. And even thats only two and a half hours worth of time. Bloody long-♥♥♥♥ firework, that.

content:
ber 2, 2016
												This game is awesome in my opinion. It sort of shows the history of games and evolution of gaming as a whole, but in its own interesting way. You start off in a Black and White 2D platformer, then 'upgrade' your game all the way to HD. It gives homage and a tip of the hat towards many gaming greats including Legend of Zelda, Final Fantasy and even Skyrim! There's many, many refrences which probably alot I missed too! Anyway a fantastic game! I absolutely loved every single minute of it. Brought me lots of nostalgic feelings towards older games in the way it makes you grind for xp, levels, abilities and money. You need to search every corner of dungeons for loot and secrets and fight hard bosses until you learn their attack patterns and just roll them. My only problem with this game is that it is too short! Honestly you can finish the game in less than an hour. The only reason my playtime is 6 hours is because I went collecting everything and getting 100%. It's not worth the full price for that little gameplay. Try to get it on sale! :D

content:
, 2014
												Evoland has really clunky controls and a poorly written story that feels hastily put together.  I beat this game and 100%'d the achievements in just over ten hours, then I uninstalled it, and I don't know if I'll ever play it again. But don't let that discourage you from making this purchase.Evoland is a wonderful trip through the history of video games.  Its a homage to the entire genre of Action/Adventure games.  Its full of quips and references to so many of the classic games centering around Zelda and Final Fantasy.  Two games I've never played, in fact I only caught a couple nods towards other games but have had friends point out many more to me.  I bought this game to enjoy a little trip down memory lane and experience what I thought was a fun way to appreciate the evolution of games.And that's exactly what this is.If you weren't around for the early days of gaming, then this game will give you that glimpse of a part of video games you've missed.  I thoroughly enjoyed every minute I spent in this game and will think fondly of it.  But it has little replay value, so I probably wont play it again.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
28, 2014
												I don't recommend Evoland.I beat the game in 2-3 hours using an x360 controller. It is neat to start out with b&w 2d graphics and slowly watch them become better, but the feeling runs dry in the first hour. The game is completely linear and serves mostly as a tech demo for all the different puzzles, playstyles, and visuals that the many adventure games of the past have already done.Any type of major puzzle used to block progress that you can think of has probably been used. Burn down saplings so that they don't block your path when you teleport to the future (Oracle of Ages/Seasons.) Find the right path to walk across a room or you will fall through the floor (Link to the Past.) Bomb through cracked walls. Find all switches. Push blocks to make a path. And so on.Most combat is in 2d Zelda format, followed by turn-based, FF style battles, and some light ARPG style combat. Evoland is not unpleasant, but with no real story, it's not exactly memorable either.

content:
9, 2014
												I really wanted to like this game, but I just can't. To best describe it, it basically tries to pay homage to The Legend of Zelda, Final Fantasy, and Diablo for the most part. The only sections I found fun in the slightest were the boss of the sole Diablo section, and very small parts of the Zelda pieces. The Final Fantasy mechanics were not enjoyable at all. It has you spamming the Action button to select your main attack, and then repeat until all the enemies die. The random encounters are especially annoying because of this. There's also a lot of questionable design choices. For instance, when you die, you go to the main menu. Rather than just get a normal game over screen. The saving is left to odd save points that end up just costing you unnecessary time. There's a lot more that I don't want to type out, though.In addition, past the first few areas, the writing is god awful. It doesn't seem to follow proper grammar, and if it does, then it's doing an extremely poor job of writing in general. First few areas had funny text, but none past that.All in all a poor game. I wouldn't reccomend spending your time or money on it.To the dev: I hope your next game is a hell of a lot better than this.

content:
2, 2015
												This charming game grabs a fistful of nostalgia and hits any gamer around during the early years straight in the face. At it's core it's a fairly simple game made up of popular mechanics that tells a tale we've already heard... but considering it's made of games we've already played, that makes sense, right? The Zelda-like dungeons were clever, although I'm a little annoyed by walk-through walls to hide collectibles.I thoroughly enjoyed the game, although I'm sad it was so short. My game time is only so high because I grabbed all the achievements; the story itself could be done in probably a 2 or 3 hour session the first time. I value games on average (more or less depending on reviews/hype) at $1 per hour of gameplay, and since I got this game on the summer sale it was very much worth it. I'd probably still recommend it at the full $10 price, but it doesn't hurt to slap it on a wishlist and wait for some sort of sale or discount. Much like a Zelda game, I'll probably not touch the game again for a few years and then randomly pick it back up to play through in an afternoon or two.I'd give this game a 7.5/10.

content:
0, 2015
												1.2 hours in: Enjoyed the quickly evolving graphics/playstyle as you run around. Hack and slash mechanics are fun, as are the turn based battles (makes me want to play some Final Fantasy games). I've gone through one dungeon and fought a boss. Wasn't difficult, more just figuring out the mechanics of the fight and doing the right thing at the right time. So far, enjoying the game and want to play more!2 hours in: I've finished the story up to the last boss. Let's be honest here, not an amazing story. The time travelling section was more tedious than creative or tricky. I plan to collect all of the hidden items in the game, but I think that may wait as I just don't really feel like playing more at the moment. But I do want to 100% the game. 6 hours in (I admit some of that time was spent afk with the game open): Just got 100% completion on the game. Was definitely tricky to find some of the hidden stars/cards, but once you figure out where you need to go, you can usually find the ones you missed the first time around (hint: wall hugging is a good idea). Some of the end game areas were rather tricky with the time travelling mechanic, so that was nice. The final boss was actually quite perfect. Took me a few tries to understand how it worked, but once I did, I was able to down him quite easily. Overall, I would say it's an enjoyable game. After the first hour, you've pretty much unlocked all of the visual and/or mechanic upgrades that you are going to get. That being said, I did enjoy playing through different game styles; it was definitely fun and brought back some great memories of other games. I don't think there is much replay-ability with this one. I would say the game is worth at least half price. Definitely enjoyable, but gets a bit repetitive after the first hour when you are going back and hunting treasures. I think I physically played the game maybe four hours, so I would recommend, but only if it's on a sale.
